qas.question: In 2007 youtube launched an automated system to detect what?
Why did the CEO of Google think the new software was necessary?
What is the name of the system that automatically detects copyright violations?
What does Content ID do if an upload is too close a match to a known copyright material?
What system did Eric Schmidt come up with?
When did Google begin trials of Content ID?

context: In <b7_0>June 2007<b7_0/>, YouTube began trials of a system for automatic detection of uploaded <a0_0>videos that infringe copyright<a0_0/>. Google CEO <a1_0><b5_0>Eric Schmidt<b5_0/><a1_0/> regarded this system as necessary for <a2_0>resolving lawsuits<a2_0/> such as the one from Viacom, which alleged that YouTube profited from content that it did not have the right to distribute. The system, which became known as <a3_0><b6_0>Content ID<b6_0/><a3_0/>, creates an ID File for copyrighted audio and video material, and stores it in a database. When a video is uploaded, it is checked against the database, and <a4_0>flags the video<a4_0/> as a copyright violation if a match is found.
